subject: Re: [junit] Re. GUI testing
msgSnippet: Hi, At XP2006 Patrick Kua from Thoughtworks demonstrated how to testdrive a Swing GUI using JUnit and Abbot. One of the key concepts was naming your components
messageBody:
Hi,

At XP2006 Patrick Kua from Thoughtworks demonstrated how to testdrive a
Swing GUI using JUnit and Abbot.
One of the key concepts was naming your components in your forms so that
they could be referenced using abbot.
I know that they also had a strategy that as long as a component exists on a
form it should not matter where it is (so if a component
changes place, size etc it should not fail the test.) They reasoned that
misplaced components is something that gets found really quickly
and that can change a lot in reviews so the focused on that everything
/worked/ and didn't try to verify the cosmetics.

I don't know what kind of components you are testing and I can imagine that
some type of graphic components can be hard to find valuable asserts for.
But I think in general if there is a will there is a way. If you want to
test a GUI you figure out how to do it. If you don't want to test a GUI you
collect evidence that it is impossible.

I have found that asking questions and really listening in this situation
can help move forward:
* are automated tests important? Why? Why not?
* what are the consequences if something doesn't work?
* why can't this be unit tested?
* is there any part that we can test today? (until we have figured out how
to test the rest)
* If it can't be unit tested, are there any other tools that can be used
that would give an acceptable level of certainty?
* if it can't be tested how can we know that it works
* can the process of knowing that it works be repeated by any one
* can the process be repeated often enough
* can the process be repeated by anyone? any developer? just one developer?

I think in this case it is a combination of a people-problem and that
testing GUI:s is really hard.
Is there any other developer that disagrees that this can't be tested?
I have also realised (better late than ever) that it is more satisfying to
look for relative improvements.
If we test more stuff today than yesterday than that is a good thing even if
we don't test as much as we
would like to test.

I would have liked to give you something concrete but I just sprayed a bunch
of stuff your way, maybe you can use some of it.
Cheers!
